concepts.concept_name: Coulomb's law (F = kq1q2/r^2), principle of superposition and electric field (E = F/q0) due to point charges
Electric field lines, electric flux and Gauss's law: phi = q_enclosed / epsilon_0 with symmetric charge distributions
Electric potential (V = kq/r), potential difference, equipotential surfaces and relation E = -dV/dr
Capacitance: parallel plate capacitor (C = epsilon_0.A/d), dielectrics, series and parallel combinations and energy stored (U = 1/2 CV^2)
Electric dipole: dipole moment (p = q.2a), field on axial and equatorial positions, torque in uniform field (tau = p x E)

in_scope: Coulomb's law numerical problems with multiple charges
Gauss's law applications: infinite line charge, infinite plane sheet, uniformly charged sphere
Potential due to a system of point charges
Capacitor combinations with and without dielectrics
Energy stored in capacitors and energy density (u = 1/2 epsilon_0 E^2)
Dipole in uniform and non-uniform electric fields
Sharing of charges between conductors
out_of_scope: Electrostatics of conductors with complex geometries

concepts.concept_name: Electric current, drift velocity (v_d = eE.tau/m), Ohm's law (V = IR) and resistance (R = rho.l/A)
Resistors in series and parallel, internal resistance of cells and Kirchhoff's laws (junction and loop rules)
Wheatstone bridge, metre bridge and potentiometer: principle and applications for measuring resistance and EMF
Electrical energy and power (P = VI = I^2R = V^2/R), temperature dependence of resistance and colour coding of resistors

in_scope: Derivation of drift velocity and its relation to current: I = nAv_d.e
Numerical problems on series-parallel resistor networks
EMF and terminal voltage: V = E - Ir
Kirchhoff's laws applied to multi-loop circuits
Wheatstone bridge balance condition: P/Q = R/S
Potentiometer: comparison of EMFs and finding internal resistance
Electrical energy consumption in kilowatt-hours
out_of_scope: AC circuit analysis with complex impedance
Semiconductor physics (covered separately in Electronic Devices)
Thermoelectric effects: Seebeck, Peltier and Thomson in detail
Network theorems: Thevenin, Norton beyond syllabus

concepts.concept_name: Biot-Savart law (dB = mu_0/4pi . Idl x r / r^3) and magnetic field due to straight conductor, circular loop and solenoid
Ampere's circuital law and its applications: magnetic field of solenoid (B = mu_0.nI) and toroid
Force on moving charge in magnetic field (F = qv x B), Lorentz force and motion of charged particle in uniform magnetic field
Force on current-carrying conductor (F = Il x B), force between parallel conductors and definition of ampere
Magnetic properties of matter: diamagnetic, paramagnetic and ferromagnetic materials, hysteresis curve and Earth's magnetism

in_scope: Magnetic field at centre and on axis of circular current loop
Magnetic field inside a long solenoid and toroid
Cyclotron: principle, frequency (f = qB/2pi.m) and limitations
Galvanometer: current sensitivity and conversion to ammeter and voltmeter
Force between two parallel current-carrying conductors
Magnetic susceptibility, permeability and their relation
Hysteresis loop and its significance for permanent magnets and electromagnets
out_of_scope: Biot-Savart law for arbitrary current distributions requiring integration
Quantum theory of magnetism and spin

concepts.concept_name: Faraday's laws of electromagnetic induction (EMF = -d(phi_B)/dt) and Lenz's law with applications
Self-inductance (L), mutual inductance (M), energy stored in inductor (U = 1/2 LI^2) and eddy currents
AC generator: principle and EMF (E = E0 sin(omega.t)), peak, RMS and average values of AC voltage and current
AC circuits: LCR series circuit, impedance (Z), phase angle, resonance (f_r = 1/(2.pi.sqrt(LC))) and power factor
Transformers: principle, turns ratio (V_s/V_p = N_s/N_p), efficiency and power transmission losses

in_scope: Motional EMF: E = Blv for a rod moving in magnetic field
Self-inductance of a solenoid: L = mu_0.n^2.A.l
Mutual inductance between coaxial solenoids
Reactance: X_L = omega.L and X_C = 1/(omega.C)
Impedance and phasor diagrams for LR, CR and LCR circuits
Resonance condition and quality factor (qualitative)
Power in AC circuits: P = V_rms.I_rms.cos(phi)
Step-up and step-down transformers with efficiency calculations

concepts.concept_name: Maxwell's displacement current, electromagnetic wave equation and properties: E and B perpendicular, transverse, speed c = 1/sqrt(mu_0.epsilon_0)
Electromagnetic spectrum: radio waves, microwaves, infrared, visible, ultraviolet, X-rays and gamma rays with wavelength ranges and uses
Energy in EM waves: Poynting vector, intensity (I = 1/2 c.epsilon_0.E0^2) and radiation pressure

in_scope: Need for displacement current and modified Ampere's law
Properties of electromagnetic waves: speed, transverse nature, polarisation
Complete electromagnetic spectrum with frequency and wavelength ranges
Sources and detectors for each region of the spectrum
Applications of different EM waves in daily life and technology
Numerical problems on c = f.lambda and intensity
out_of_scope: Derivation of wave equation from Maxwell's equations
Polarisation techniques in detail (covered under Optics)

concepts.concept_name: Reflection and refraction at spherical surfaces, lens maker's equation (1/f = (n-1)(1/R1 - 1/R2)) and thin lens formula (1/v - 1/u = 1/f)
Optical instruments: human eye, microscope (simple and compound) and telescope (refracting and reflecting) with magnifying power
Wave optics: Huygens' principle, interference (Young's double slit: fringe width beta = lambda.D/d) and conditions for constructive and destructive interference
Diffraction: single slit pattern (minima at a sin(theta) = n.lambda), resolving power of microscope and telescope
Polarisation: Malus's law (I = I0 cos^2(theta)), Brewster's law (tan(i_p) = n) and polaroids

in_scope: Mirror formula (1/v + 1/u = 1/f) and magnification for spherical mirrors
Refraction through prism: deviation and dispersive power
Total internal reflection: critical angle and optical fibres
Combination of thin lenses in contact: 1/f = 1/f1 + 1/f2
Young's double slit experiment: fringe width and intensity distribution
Single slit diffraction pattern: central maximum width and secondary maxima
Polarisation by reflection, refraction and double refraction
out_of_scope: Aberrations: spherical and chromatic in quantitative detail
Matrix optics and thick lens formulae
Multiple beam interference and Fabry-Perot interferometer
Fresnel diffraction and zone plate theory

concepts.concept_name: Photoelectric effect: Einstein's equation (KE_max = hf - phi), threshold frequency, stopping potential and experimental observations
Photon model of light: energy (E = hf), momentum (p = h/lambda) and radiation pressure
de Broglie hypothesis: matter waves (lambda = h/mv), experimental verification and Davisson-Germer experiment
Photoelectric effect graphs: photocurrent vs intensity, stopping potential vs frequency and KE_max vs frequency

in_scope: Hertz and Lenard experimental observations on photoelectric effect
Einstein's photoelectric equation and numerical problems
Work function in eV and Joules for common metals
de Broglie wavelength of electrons accelerated through potential V: lambda = h/sqrt(2meV)
Graphical analysis of photoelectric effect data
Photon energy and momentum calculations
out_of_scope: Wave function and quantum mechanical probability

concepts.concept_name: Bohr model of hydrogen atom: energy levels (E_n = -13.6/n^2 eV), spectral series and radius (r_n = 0.529 n^2 angstrom)
Nuclear structure: atomic number, mass number, isotopes, nuclear size (R = R0.A^(1/3)) and nuclear density
Radioactivity: alpha, beta and gamma decay, decay law (N = N0.e^(-lambda.t)), half-life (T_1/2 = 0.693/lambda) and activity
Mass-energy equivalence (E = mc^2), mass defect, binding energy per nucleon curve and nuclear stability
Nuclear fission and fusion: energy released, chain reaction, critical mass and controlled fusion conditions

in_scope: Rutherford scattering experiment and nuclear model of atom
Bohr's postulates and derivation of energy levels for hydrogen
Spectral series: Lyman, Balmer, Paschen and their wavelength ranges
Radioactive decay equations and half-life numerical problems
Binding energy per nucleon curve and explanation of fission and fusion
Q-value of nuclear reactions
Nuclear reactor: components and working principle
out_of_scope: Quantum mechanical model of atom and orbital shapes
Nuclear shell model and magic numbers
Particle physics: quarks, leptons and standard model
Plasma confinement methods for fusion in detail

concepts.concept_name: Semiconductor physics: energy bands, intrinsic and extrinsic semiconductors (n-type and p-type), charge carrier concentration
p-n junction diode: formation of depletion layer, forward and reverse bias, V-I characteristics and breakdown
Diode applications: half-wave and full-wave rectifiers, Zener diode as voltage regulator and LED and photodiode
Logic gates: OR, AND, NOT, NAND and NOR gates, truth tables and NAND/NOR as universal gates

in_scope: Energy band diagrams for conductors, semiconductors and insulators
Doping and majority/minority carriers
Diode equation qualitatively and V-I characteristic curves
Rectifier circuits with and without filter capacitor
Zener breakdown and voltage regulation circuit
Truth tables for basic logic gates
Combination of gates to form other gates (e.g., NAND to AND)
LED, photodiode and solar cell working principles

concepts.concept_name: Elements of communication system: transmitter, channel and receiver, bandwidth and signal-to-noise ratio
Modulation: need for modulation, amplitude modulation (AM), frequency modulation (FM) and modulation index
Propagation of electromagnetic waves: ground wave, sky wave (ionospheric reflection) and space wave (line of sight: d = sqrt(2Rh))
Bandwidth of signals: speech, music and video, bandwidth allocation and frequency spectrum for AM and FM transmission

in_scope: Block diagram of a communication system
Bandwidth requirements for audio, video and data signals
Amplitude modulation: carrier, sidebands and bandwidth = 2f_m
Modulation index (m = A_m/A_c) and its significance
Range of ground wave, sky wave and space wave propagation
Line of sight distance formula and numerical problems
Detection (demodulation) of AM signals
out_of_scope: Digital modulation techniques: ASK, FSK, PSK
Optical fibre communication in engineering detail
